content: hi @T-compiler/meeting , we will be starting our tetra-weekly planning meeting in about 30 minutes.
Hi again @T-compiler/meeting . I’m starting the meeting now; add a :wave: to show you’re here

We’ll start off with a few minutes for

Announcements
okay then, lets look at the current meeting proposals: https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-team/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3Ameeting-proposal+-label%3Ameeting-scheduled
nothing new since the last planning meeting
two proposals:

• compiler-team#400: perf triage report construction
  • compiler-team#415: dylibs need directors
So, I’ll speak on compiler-team#415 first: I suspect the situation there is much the same as it was at the last planning meeting
you can see that discussion here: https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/238009-t-compiler.2Fmeetings/topic/.5Bplanning.20meeting.5D.202021-03-12/near/230047100
Namely: It would be good to get some stake-holders to document what the current problems are, and then we can talk about solutions
but: We probably should not try to construct that documentation in an ad-hoc hour-long synchronous meeting
so the real question is whether there is any stake-holder who expects to be able to generate such a doc in time for a meeting
I know that I probably won’t have time, unless I generate it as notes from investgation of rust#82151
This feels like the kind of issue that is ultimately important to resolve but not urgent and so it's difficult for us to find time to address it.
so I’ll just assert that we should (again) table rust#82151 compiler-team#415, and maybe I should withdraw it entirely until I’ve either created a doc or found someone who can generate the doc
is there value in having the meeting proposal sitting there opened but perpetually tabled, if only as a kick in my butt to remind me to think about writing something?
I think I’ll withdrwa it

table rust#82151

Table the bug or table the meeting request?
table the meeting request, sorry
Now, as for compiler-team#400
is @rylev around today?
:wave::wave:
awesome

I was just looking at the last planning meetings discussion of compiler-team#400: https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/238009-t-compiler.2Fmeetings/topic/.5Bplanning.20meeting.5D.202021-03-12/near/230045715

from there:

the question is whether we’re at a stage where a steering [meeting] with the team would be useful or not
I'm happy with the proposal, but it seems others weren't necessarily enthusiastic.
well, a dedicated synchronous discussion might help tease apart what the issues are
I don't think I would have time to do the work alone, and I'm not sure who else would be willing to help
as @simulacrum said, “change is hard"
but the maintaining the current system may be even harder
is there a zulip topic discussing the doc somewhere?
https://zulip-archive.rust-lang.org/247081tcompilerperformance/70522Theshorttermperformanceprocessreview.html I think ?
Yes - https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/247081-t-compiler.2Fperformance/topic/The.20short-term.20performance.20process.20review
oh right, I even linked it in a comment on compiler-team#400 I think :lol:
okay
Having a discussion about it and possibly creating a list of items to work on would go a long way. We might be able to recruit help then

I think if we have identified potential improvements, it's worth discussing them even if the outcome is that we do not implement them for some reason. Improving the the performance triage process is going to be iterative anyway.
personally, I think the zulip chat didn’t seem that bad. I.e. I don’t think I saw people outright objecting
I think we could safely schedule a meeting
even if its just to discuss the writeup as written
which means no new work for rylev to prepare for the meeting, I think. We would just want to be sure that rylev can attend the meeting.
okay
there was one more thing I just reailzed I probably should have put up as a meeting proposal
I’ve been privately circulating a set of “Guiding Principles” for the rust compiler contributors
basically, its my attempt to try to document the ideals that drive a lot of our decisions in our part of the project
its been suggested that I turn it into an RFC
which might be the right answer for the end-point of that document
But, would anyone be interested in first having a design meeting about it?
I might as well link it here at this point, I guess
https://hackmd.io/TYGRjVIbSBmxpbcfDzll-w?view
Let me actually make a proper issue on the compiler-team repo
okay just filed compiler-team#424 for that
so, I think we now have on the table, potentially, two meetings: compiler-team#400, and compiler-team#424
and we have three steering meeting slots:

• april 16
  • april 23
  • april 30
First off: does anyone know of any public holidays on any of those days?
(I don’t want to fall into same trap that I landed in four weeks ago… :bunny: )
okay, next question: @rylev , which of those days is best for you, for compiler-team#400? (And I think I’d also like to make sure @simulacrum can attend too, if possible.)
I should be available any of those days.
I am OK with any of the three, too, though mild preference for first two.
okay. I don’t know if there’s any particular rush for either topic
of course the next release is may 6th
which may mean april 30th could be a bad meeting time
Lets do april 16th and april 23rd
how does compiler-team#400 on april 16th, and compiler-team#424 on april 23rd sound?
(any objections….?)
Seems fine to me!
okay well I’m inclined to end the planning meeting early then!
(Welll, we could work through MCP backlog …)
(but I’m not feeling that today. Lets chalk it up to side-effects of covid vaccine…)
thanks to everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending!

@T-compiler/meeting just wanted to let you all know that we won’t be able to hold the compiler-team#400 meeting on April 16th after all. :sad: @rylev says they can do it on April 30th, so I’m going to move it to that date.
